Fig. 1 XRD patterns (a) and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and desorption pore size distribution (b) of Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 XPS spectra of Pt 4f (a) and Nb 3d (b) for Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 H2-TPR profile of oxide Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts. Catalyst was cooled in flowing He to 50 °C and then heated at 10 °C/min of flowing 10 % H2/He to 1000 °C. Fig 3 Fig. 4 High-resolution TEM, FFT and SAED images of 1Pt0Nb (a-c), 1Pt2Nb (d-f), 1Pt4Nb (g-i) and 1Pt6Nb (j-l). The insets show the Pt size distribution of the catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Py-IR spectra at 1560–1400 cm−1(a) and NH3-TPD spectra (d) of Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts. Fig 5 Fig. 6 FT-IR at 3800–3620 cm−1 (a), and its corresponding area ratio of IR bands(3729, 3700 and 3670 cm−1/3700 cm−1) vs relative content of Nb2O5 on catalysts (b), H2O-TPD spectra (c) and static contact angle measured for Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts with water (left) and guaiacol (right) (d). Fig 6 Fig. 7 Catalytic performance on HDO of guaiacol. (a) Product distribution over NbxAl2O3.3 supports and Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts and (b) rHDO of guaiacol on unit of Pt sites as function of relative surface hydroxyl amount for Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts with water. Reaction condition: 2 g catalyst, 200 g 10 % guaiacol in decalin, 4 MPa H2, 280 °C, 6 h, reaction mixture was stirred at 500 rpm. rHDO: reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons on unit of Pt sites. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Product distribution and guaiacol conversion after HDO of guaiacol over a) 1Pt2Nb and b) 1Pt0Nb as a function of time. Reaction condition: 200 g 10 % guaiacol in decalin, 1.5 g catalyst, 4 MPa H2, 320 °C, stirred at 500 rpm. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Product distribution for reactions over γ-Al2O3, 2Nb, 1Pt0Nb and 1Pt2Nb. Reaction condition: 200 g 10 % guaiacol in decalin, 4 MPa H2, 320 °C, 6 h, reaction mixture was stirred at 500 rpm. Fig 9 Scheme 1 Schematic presentation of the regulation of surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion on Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface during the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of guaicol into bio-hydrocarbons. The enhanced hydrophobicty promotes the desorption of produced water, acheiveing higher reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons on unit of metal sites, while the improved Pt nanoparticle dispersion enhances the number of active sites for HDO reaction of guaiacol, leading to further higher hydrocarbons yield on catalyst. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Proposed HDO reaction pathway of guaiacol over Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalyst. Note: Blue bold lines represent accelerated reaction steps. State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing College of Chemical Engineering China University of Petroleum Qingdao 266580 China Transformation of lignin-derived feedstocks into valuable hydrocarbons is of significant importance but still challenging. This work investigates the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin compound guaiacol on Pt-based catalysts with improved surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion for the first time. The efficiency of guaiacol hydrodeoxygenation into hydrocarbons over Nb2O5-modified Pt-based catalyst reaches 51 %, nearly doubling that over unmodified Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (25 %). On the one hand, Nb2O5 causes the decrease of hydroxyl groups on catalyst, leading to the enhanced hydrophobicity of catalysts, which increases the reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons on unit of Pt metal sites. On the other hand, Nb2O5 strengthens the metal-support interaction, which minimizes the size of Pt nanoparticles, providing more exposed metal sites, thus leading to a higher hydrocarbons yield on catalyst. However, excess introduction of Nb2O5 leads to partial coverage of Pt metal sites, resulting in decreased yield of hydrocarbons. Furthermore, the routes of guaiacol HDO reaction over modified Pt-based catalysts are investigated. This work further illustrates the influence of catalyst surface properties on the HDO process of lignin compound, and thereby provides a promising approach for adjustment of catalyst surface properties in order to promote water-liberated reactions. Graphical abstracts Schematic presentation of the regulation of surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion on Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface during the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of guaicol into bio-hydrocarbons. The enhanced hydrophobicty promotes the desorption of produced water, acheiveing higher reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons on unit of metal sites, while the improved Pt nanoparticle dispersion enhances the number of active sites for HDO reaction of guaiacol, leading to a higher hydrocarbons yield on catalyst. Introduction As a renewable carbon resource in nature, biomass provides promising advantages in producing green bio-hydrocarbons [1]. Lignin, as a primary component of biomass, is the most abundant resource of aromatics in nature [2]. In recent years, lignin has become a potential raw material for the production of chemicals in order to develop a sustainable and carbon-neutral refinery to supplement or replace fossil fuels [2–4]. Several strategies have been developed in lignin upgrading, including fast prolysis [5], oxidation [6], enzymolysis [7], hydrotreating [8–10], etc. Among them, the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) process is an effective and green technology for lignin upgrading, which requires mild reaction conditions, exhibits high hydrocarbons yields and produces water as the only co-product [11–14] . Many recent studies focus on noble metal catalysts for efficient hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin compounds [15–17]. To achieve good HDO efficiency of lignin compounds, oxide-supported noble metal-based catalysts, such as Pt/γ-Al2O3 [18], Pd/SiO2 [19], Rh/SiO2 [20], Rh/ZrO2 [20], etc., were designed. However, the yields of hydrocarbons are still unsatisfactory on these catalysts. To enhance the hydrocarbons yield, the HDO catalysts are modified according to the reaction mechanism of lignin compounds. The HDO reactions of lignin compounds involve four steps [21]: (1) activation of hydrogen on metal sites, (2) adsorption of lignin compound on acid sites, (3) attraction of CO bond by activated hydrogen (produces water molecules) and (4) desorption of water molecules on acid sites. It is widely reported that (1) and (3) steps could be accelerated by improving the metal dispersion on catalyst, which provides more active metal sites for the HDO of lignin compounds [11,22]. The (2) step can be accelerated by enhancing the amounts of acid sites on catalyst surface [23]. The (4) step can be accelerated by regulating the surface hydrophobicity of catalyst, which can promote the desorption of water molecules on acid sites. As reported, Wang [24] designed a carbon-coated CoS2−MoS2 catalyst to enhance the hydrophobicity on catalyst surface, which prevents the adsorption of water on active sites, and thus enhances the HDO activity of 4-ethylphenol on the catalyst. Unfortunately, the leaching sulfur on sulfide Mo-based catalysts easily incorporates into products and inevitably causes environmental pollutions [20,24]. Thus, the HDO efficiency of lignin compounds can be boosted by accelerating any one of the four steps. It is reasonable to achieve an even higher hydrocarbons yield by accelerating two or more of the four steps in the HDO process of lignin compounds. In our previous study, it is proved that Nb species helps to improve the metal dispersion on MoS2-based catalyst by affecting the metal-support interaction(MSI) [25]. On the other hand, Nb species can effectively enhance the hydrophobicity of catalysts due to the hydrophobic surface of Nb2O5[26], which should be considered as an important factor in the HDO of lignin compounds and has not been reported up to now. Above all, it is reasonable to believe that the HDO efficiency of lignin compounds can be enhanced effectively by regulation of both of surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion on Pt-based catalyst with Nb species, which promotes the (1), (3) and (4) steps at the same time. However, recent studies have shown that Nb2O5 helps to promote the HDO reactions of lignin model compounds on noble metal catalysts, which is contributed to the influence of Nb2O5 on the acidity of catalysts [27,28]. Some other researchers [29,30] have attributed the enhanced HDO activity to the strong interaction between the Nb5+/Nb4+ cations (oxophilic sites) and the oxygen from lignin compound. These studies mainly focus on the promotion of Nb2O5 on the (2) step in the HDO process. As reported, niobium oxides cannot function as solid acids for acid-catalyzed reactions after calcination at high temperature above 450 °C because of complete elimination of the intrinsic Brønsted and Lewis acidity of amorphous niobium oxide by calcination [26,31]. Thus, to eliminate the influence of acidity provided by Nb2O5 and thus give clearer insights into the influence of surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion on catalyst performance, the Pt-based catalysts are prepared with low molar content of Nb (0–0.015) and high calcination temperature (500 °C) of supports in this work. In this work, the catalytic performance is boosted by designing a series of Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts with varied Nb contents on γ-Al2O3 support. The underlying structure-performance relationship for the HDO reaction is systematically elucidated by various characterization means, such as XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, H2O-TPD, FT-IR and contact angle analysis. It is found that the Nb species significantly enhance the reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons on unit of Pt metal sites by enhancing the hydrophobicity of catalyst surface, and influence the hydrocarbons yield on catalysts by changing the Pt nanoparticles dispersion. Furthermore, the HDO reaction routes of guaiacol over Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts were investigated. Above all, this work focuses on the influence of surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion on HDO catalytic performance of lignin model compound and provides a promising approach for facilitating catalytic reactions that produces water. Experimental Materials Chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6·6H2O, >99 %), decalin (C10H18, >99 %), guaiacol (C7H8O2, >99 %), niobium oxalate (C10H5NbO20, >99 %) were purchased from Aladdin (China); and alumina(γ-Al2O3) was purchased from Henghui (China). Distilled and deionized (DDI) water was prepared using a filtration system (Aodlon, China). Catalyst preparation The Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts were prepared by a two-step incipient-wetness impregnation method. First, C10H5NbO20 solution was prepared by dissolving niobium oxalate in 13.5 g of DDI water, then the solution was used to impregnate 15 g of γ-Al2O3 support by incipient impregnation method, with the Nb2O5/γ-Al2O3 ratio of 0, 2, 4 and 6 wt%. The obtained samples were dried at 120 °C for 8 h and then calcined at 500 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace and named as 0 Nb, 2Nb, 4Nb, and 6Nb. Secondly, 0.398 g of H2PtCl6·6H2O was dissolved in DDI water to prepare an H2PtCl6·6H2O solution. The operation was repeated to prepare four H2PtCl6·6H2O solutions, with which 0 Nb, 2Nb, 4Nb, and 6Nb were impregnated by incipient impregnation method, respectively. The resulting catalyst samples were calcined at 400 °C for 4 h and then reduced with H2 in a tube furnace at 400 °C for 6 h and named 1Pt0Nb, 1Pt2Nb, 1Pt4Nb and 1Pt6Nb with the Nb/Al/O atomic ratio of 0/2/3.3, 0.006/2/3.32, 0.009/2/3.3 and 0.015/2/3.3 (according to the XPS results in Table S1), respectively. Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out on an X'Pert PRO MPD X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ=0.15406 nm) at a voltage and current of 40 kV and 40 mA. The 2θ was scanned over the range 10∼75° at a rate of 10°/min. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size were measured by an Autosorb iQ automated gas sorption analyzer by physisorption of nitrogen at −196 °C. The samples were dehydrated at 300 °C using vacuum degassing for 3 h before experiments. The IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine were recorded on a Bruker TENSOR 27 FT-IR spectrometer operating at the resolution of 4 cm−1. 10 mg of catalyst samples were activated at vacuum (P = 10−3 Pa) at 400 °C for 1 h, then equilibrated with pyridine at 50 °C for 30 min, and finally evacuated for 30 min. The spectra were recorded till equilibrium. NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted with AutoChem Ⅱ 2950 HP (Micromeritics, America) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to testing, 100 mg of the sample was purged with helium at 350 °C for 40 min, cooled to 55 °C, saturated with NH3 for 30 min, purged with helium again for 30 min to remove physisorbed NH3, and heated to 800 °C under helium blanket with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The concentration of acidic sites was quantified by stoichiometry (NH3: acid site= 1:1). NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (H2O-TPD) was conducted with TP-5076 automatic adsorption and desorption device (China). Prior to testing, 100 mg of the sample was purged with helium at 90 °C for 30 min to remove surface adsorbed material, then cooled to 30 °C, and saturated with water vapor (30 mL/min) for 60 min. After saturation, the sample was purged with helium again for 30 min to remove physisorbed H2O and heated to 800 °C under helium blanket with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) profiles were measured with the AutoChem Ⅱ 2950 HP (Micromeritics, America) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In a typical run, 0.2 g of the catalyst was pretreated in Ar (50 mL/min) at 300 °C for 2 h and then cooled to ambient temperature. After that, 10 vol% H2/Ar gas was introduced at the flow rate of 50 mL/min. The catalyst was heated to 1000 °C (10 °C/min). During the run, H2 was detected by a TCD detector. The Pt dispersion was calculated by CO pulse chemisorption using a Belcat-Ⅱ automatic chemisorption instrument (MicrotracBEL, Japan). The samples were purged in helium for 30 min. Pulses of 5 % CO/He were repeatedly dosed into the system until the sample was completely saturated with chemisorbed CO. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis were performed on an Axis Autra DLD X-ray photoelectron spectrometer at the natural scanning range of 500 μm with Mg/Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). The carbonaceous C1s line (284.6 eV) was used as reference to calibrate the binding energies. The morphology of the catalysts was observed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100, Japan). The wetting characteristics of catalysts were investigated by sessile drop method by a Sl200B contact angle goniometer (Solon Tech., China). The contact angle measurement was repeated for three times to confirm the accuracy. The oxygen content was determined by a Unicube elemental analyzer (Elementar, Germany), while the contents of platinum, niobium and aluminum were determined by ICP-OES (Agilent Technologies, 720ES Series). Catalyst performance evaluation The Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts were tested on their catalytic performance in a 500 mL autoclave. Typically, 20 g of guaiacol, 180 g of decalin and 2 g of catalyst were fed into a reactor. Hydrogen was supplied to the reactor 3∼5 times to remove air from the reactor. After that, hydrogen was supplied to the reactor again till the pressure arrived 2.5 MPa. The system was heated to a preset temperature and reacted for designated time at the stirring speed of 500 r/min. Catalyst performance evaluation The products were analyzed using a GC/MS system consisting of a Varian 3400 capillary column gas chromatography and a Finnigan SSQ 710 quadrupole mass spectra (MS). The conversion, yield, hydrodeoxygenation efficiency and HDO reaction rate of guaiacol were calculated as follows: (1) Conversion = mol of guaiacol consumed/ mol of guaiacolinit × 100 (1) (2) Yield = mol of product produced/mol of guaiacolinit × 100 (2) (3) HDO=mol of Hydrocarbons/ mol of guaiacol consumed × 100 (3) (4) rHDO=mol of hydrocarbons/(mols of exposed Pt sites × reaction time) (4) Results and discussion Catalyst characterization XRD patterns in Fig. 1 a show the typical diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 19.44°, 31.96°, 37.33°, 39.42°, 46.27°, 61.03°and 66.69°, which correspond to different crystal faces of crystalline structure of the γ-Al2O3 with (111), (220), (222), (400), (511) and (440), respectively (PDF 00–029–0063). No characteristic peak of Pt or Nb is observed, which indicates that Pt and Nb species are dispersed well on catalyst surface. Fig. 1b shows N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and desorption pore size distribution. All the catalysts show similar type Ⅳ isotherms with an H4-type hysteresis loop, suggesting the mesopores structure features. Pore size distribution derived from the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model shows that all the catalysts exhibit mesoporosity between 6.5 and10.4 nm. Table 1 shows that with the increase of Nb content, both of the surface area and total pore volume of NbxAl2O3.3 and Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts slightly decrease, which could be attributed to partial blockage with the introduction of Nb species. The NbxAl2O3.3 supports and Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts have very similar average pore size at around 7.3 nm, but 1Pt2Nb (8.4 nm) has the largest average pore size among all catalysts. The XPS analysis of catalysts were conducted to illustrate the chemical composition and the metal-support interaction (MSI). The survey spectra of Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalyst show Al, O, Pt, Nb and C elements (Fig. S1, Supporting information). The binding energies (B.E.) of Pt 4d, O 1 s and Nb 3d are listed in Table S1. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, Pt 4d3/2 and Pt 4d5/2 at 332.0 and 314.6 eV are attributed to peaks of Pt(0), which confirms that Pt species in all Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts exist in reduced state. The peaks appear at around 306 eV are assigned to Mg auger peak, which is due to the analysis by Mg/Al Kα radiation. The peak of Pt 4d shifts to higher B.E with doping of Nb into Pt/γ-Al2O3, which is attributed to the interaction between Pt and support or smaller size of Pt NPs. However, further doping of Nb does not have obvious influence on Pt particle size (Fig. 4), while peaks of Pt 4d shift to higher B.E., indicating that the interaction between Pt and support is the decisive influence factor of Pt 4d peak shift. The Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts exhibit three peaks of O 1 s at the binding energy of around 530.6, 531.3 and 533.0 eV (Fig. S2), corresponding to Nb-O, Al-O and surface oxygen species, respectively [32]. As shown in the XPS spectra of Nb 3d (Fig. 2b), the peaks at 207.2 eV (Nb 3d5/2) and 209.9 eV (Nb 3d3/2), which are assigned to Nb (Ⅴ), indicate the existence of Nb5+ on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts [33]. No peak of Nb species in other valence state is found, and Nb-O is the only bond for Nb with O as shown in Fig. S2, indicating that Nb species exists in the form of Nb2O5 as the dominant species for Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts. It is found that the peak intensity of Nb 3d5/2 and Nb 3d3/2 increases with increasing Nb content on catalysts. In addition, the doping of Nb into catalysts leads to the peak shift of Nb to lower B.E. and Pt 4d to higher B.E. (Fig. 2), implying the electron transfer from the surface of Pt to NbxAl2O3.3 support and an interaction between Pt and support (MSI) on catalysts. To give insights into the reducibility of catalysts and MSI on catalysts, the fresh PtO/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts were tested by H2-TPR (Fig. 3 ). H2-TPR results show that the main peaks appeared at 180∼300 and 600∼800 °C, corresponding to the reduction of PtOx and Nb2O5, respectively. When Nb2O5 is introduced into γ-Al2O3, a reduction peak appears at 600–800 °C. The intensity of the reduction peak increases steadily with increasing the content of Nb2O5 on NbxAl2O3.3 supports, illustrating that the reduction of Nb2O5 happens at 600–800 °C on NbxAl2O3.3 supports. With increasing the Nb content, the reduction peaks of Nb shift to lower temperature, indicating weakened interaction between Nb2O5 and γ-Al2O3 because of the alteration of the electronic structure of Nb2O5 or a larger particle size of Nb2O5. For the Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts, the reduction peaks of Pt appeared at around 300 °C. With doping Nb into catalysts, the reduction peaks of Pt shifted to higher temperature, suggesting that Nb effectively weakened the reducibility of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) on catalysts and strengthened the interaction between Pt NPs and support. Furthermore, the reduction peaks of Nb become flatter and broader and shift to lower temperature (400–700 °C) than those of NbxAl2O3.3 supports, which is due to the alteration of the electronic structure of Nb2O5 resulted from electron transfer from Pt to Nb species. Above all, Nb2O5 strengthens the interaction between Pt and supports, coinciding with the peak shift of Nb3d and Pt4d in XPS result (Fig. 2). Fig. 4 shows the high-resolution TEM and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) images of Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts, and Fig. S3 shows the HAADF-STEM image and the corresponding elemental mappings of 1Pt2Nb catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 4, Pt NPs are homogeneously disperse on all catalysts. The observed lattice fringes of 0.231 and 0.197 nm can be indexed to the Pt (111) [34] and Pt (200) [35] planes, which has been confirmed by the fast Fourier transformation (FFT) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) images. Moreover, irregularly shaped Nb2O5 shows lattice fringes of 0.193 nm, which corresponds to Nb2O5 (002)[36] lattice plane. As shown in the HRTEM image, the particle size of Pt NPs on 1Pt0Nb distributes between 1 and 7 nm with average size of about 3.4 nm. However, with the introduction of Nb, the average particle size of Pt NPs on 1Pt2Nb, 1Pt4Nb and 1Pt6Nb significantly decreases to 1.6∼1.8 nm, indicating that the doping of Nb can significantly reduce the particle size of Pt nanoparticles. It is attributed to the stabilization of Pt NPs promoted by SMSI on catalysts [36,37], coinciding with the reduction peaks of PtOx species at higher temperature in H2-TPR results. The EDS images and the corresponding element mapping analysis of 1Pt2Nb confirm the existence of Al, O, Nb and Pt elements, with Pt and Nb species homogeneously dispersed on 1Pt2Nb. As shown in Table 1, the Pt dispersion of Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts are calculated by CO pulse chemisorption. The minimized size of Pt NPs effectively improves the dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on catalyst surface from 42.0 % on 1Pt0Nb to 58 % on 1Pt2Nb. However, with further doping of Nb, the dispersion of Pt decreases continuously from 57.6% to 35.2%, which is attributed to partial coverage of Nb on Pt because of excess Nb content. Py-IR (Fig. 5 a) and NH3-TPD (Fig. 5b) were conducted to investigate the acidity of catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5a, the two bands at around 1445 and 1458 cm−1 can be attributed to two Lewis acid (L-acid) sites, corresponding to H-bonded pyridine and coordinated pyridine, respectively [38–40]. No characteristic peak of Brønsted acid (B-acid) site at 1540 cm−1 is observed. The peak at 1490 cm−1 corresponds to total acid sites. NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts show only one peak of l-acid site at around 1445 cm−1 and another peak of total acid sites at around 1490 cm−1. New peaks at 1460 cm−1 on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts could be attributed to 19b ν(CC) vibrations of pyridine adsorbed at Lewis acid sites [41]. The similar spectra of all catalysts suggests that the doping of Nb does not has significant influence on both of amounts of l-acid and total acid sites. For Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts, the increase of Nb content does not significantly influence the amounts of acid sites, in which all the spectra of are Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts quite similar. As shown in the NH3-TPD profile (Fig. 5d, Fig. S5 and Table 1), three desorption peaks are observed at 80∼160, 160∼260 and 260∼550 °C, which represent weak (W-acid), medium-strong (M-acid) and strong (S-acid) acid sites of catalysts, respectively. The introduction of Nb causes slight decrease of acid sites as shown in Table 2, which is caused by partial coverage of acidic sites by Nb2O5. The overlapped curves of all Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts indicates similar amounts of acid sites on catalyst, suggesting that the doping of Nb does not has obvious influence on acidity of the prepared catalysts, which coincides with the Py-IR results. FT-IR among the hydroxyl region [42], H2O-TPD [43] and static contact angle of catalysts with water [44] are shown in Fig. 6 a-6b, 6c and 6d, which are typical characterizations to investigate the hydrophobicity of the catalyst. As reported [45], surface –OH groups are responsible for hydrophilicity of catalyst, which are able to form hydrogen bonds with water, providing a property that increases the hydrophilicity of catalyst surface. The –OH groups are characterized by FT-IR among the hydroxyl region (3600–3800 cm−1) [42]. As shown in Fig. 5a, three bands of –OH groups are found in the IR spectrum at 3670, 3700 and 3729 cm−1. As shown in Fig. 5a, the area of bands at 3729 and 3670 cm−1 both decrease, while the area of bands at 3700 cm−1 remains unchanged with the enhancement of Nb2O5 content on catalyst. To elucidate the relationship between surface hydrophilicity and Nb2O5 content on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts, the plot of A3729+3700+3670/A3700 (area of all band/area of band at 3700 cm−1) vs. Relative content of Nb2O5 on catalyst with constant intensity of the band at 3700 cm−1 is shown in Fig. 5b. The plot of A3729+3700+3670/A3700 vs. Nb2O5 content shows a nearly liner relationship, which indicates that the decrease of –OH groups on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts was primarily related to Nb2O5 content on catalysts, leading to improved hydrophobicity of catalyst surface. This should be due to coverage of γ-Al2O3 surface with niobium oxide [45]. As shown in Fig. 6c (H2O-TPD), the highest intensity peak of water desorption is observed on 1Pt0Nb. With increasing the amount of Nb on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts, both of the desorption temperature and peak area decreases in the order of 1Pt0Nb > 1Pt2Nb > 1Pt4Nb > 1Pt6Nb, proving the weakened adsorption of water and thus better hydrophobicity with the aid of Nb, which concides with the IR results. In addition, the differences in hydrophobic nature on NbxAl2O3.3 supports and Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts are proved by their contact angle (CA) with water and guaiacol. As shown in Figs. S4 and 6d, CA of water increases with increasing Nb content on both of supports and catalysts. CA on NbxAl2O3.3 supports increases in the order of γ-Al2O3 (19.7°)> 2Nb (∼22.5°) > 4Nb (∼25.1°) > 6Nb(∼32.8°), while CA on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts increases in the order of γ-Al2O3 (12.4°)> 2Nb (20.4°) > 4Nb (23.2°) > 6Nb(31.2°). Element analysis data in Table S4 showed the element content of Pt, Al, Nb and O on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts. HDO results of guaiacol To reveal the effect of Nb species on the HDO reaction of guaiacol, HDO reaction of guaiacol over catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 a and the reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons on unit metal sites of Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 were calculated (Fig. 7b and Table S2). As illustrated in Fig. 7a, the main products of guaiacol HDO reaction are phenols, ketones, hydrocarbons and ethers. The support γ-Al2O3 exhibits low catalytic activity and thus low conversion (8.7 %) of guaiacol and low yield of hydrocarbons (0.2 %). In the presence of NbxAl2O3.3 supports, guaiacol yields 0.04 % hydrocarbons over Nb0.03Al2O3.3 without Pt metal sites, with phenols as the main product. Thus, Nb2O5 has slight hydrogenation activity. On Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts with different Nb content, guaiacol reacts into phenols (phenol, catechol and 3-methylcatechol), ketones (cyclohexanone), hydrocarbons (cyclohexane, methylcyclohexane) and ethers (anisole and veratrole, 3-methylveratrole). Table S2 shows that with increasing temperature, both of the conversion and HDO efficiency of guaiacol increase, but the HDO efficiency increases more slowly than conversion. That is because the intermediate products with two oxygen atoms (O2) and one oxygen atom (O1), and hydrocarbons were produced during guaiacol HDO reaction. With increasing temperature, the guaiacol conversion grows faster than HDO efficiency due to O2 and O1 (Fig. S6). As shown in Fig. 7a, the much higher conversion of guaiacol on all Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts at 42 % (320 °C) than that on NbxAl2O3.3 supports indicates that Pt NPs is a crucial factor in the HDO reaction. On the other hand, cyclohexanone is obtained only in the presence of Pt, indicating that the formation of cyclohexanone is dominated by Pt metal sites. It coincided with the decrease of ketones yield with increasing Nb content because of partial coverage of Pt metal sites by Nb2O5, which is proved by CO pulse chemisorption results. The hydrocarbons yield over 1Pt2Nb (51 %) is nearly twice that over 1Pt0Nb (25 %), but further doping of Nb negatively influences the guaiacol HDO reaction, showing a sharp decrease of HDO efficiency over 1Pt4Nb (41 %) and 1Pt6Nb (35 %). It should be emphasized that the hydrocarbons yield over Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts is not equal to the sum of those over NbxAl2O3.3 and Pt/γ-Al2O3, confirming the synergistic effect of Nb on Pt-based catalysts in the HDO of guaiacol. To summarize, a moderate amount of Nb enhances the HDO activity of Pt-based catalysts, but an excess of Nb leads to significant decrease in catalytic activity of Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts. On the one hand, the HDO activity of 1Pt2Nb increases due to the fact that the improved Pt NPs dispersion from 42.0 % (1Pt0Nb) to 57.6 % (1Pt2Nb) promotes the adsorption of H2 on more metal sites. However, higher Nb content on catalysts causes partial coverage of Pt active sites on catalysts and thus a decrease of Pt NPs dispersion from 57.6 % (1Pt2Nb) to 35.2 % (1Pt6Nb) (Table 1) and a decrease of hydrocarbons yield. The reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons on unit of exposed Pt was calculated and noted as rHDO with low guaiacol conversion below 20 %. Fig. 7b and Table S2 show that with increasing Nb content on catalyst, rHDO of guaiacol on unit of metal sites increases steadily from 0.024 to 0.032 min−1, the plot of rHDO vs. amount of surface hydroxyl groups shows a negative linear relationship. As proved in Section 3.1, the decreased amount of surface hydroxyl groups (A3729+3700+3670/A3700) is responsible for the improved hydrophilicity. It indicates that the improved surface hydrophilicity is the key influencing factor of HDO activity on unit of Pt sites. This could be due to two reasons. Firstly, electronegative water molecules could quench energetic electrons, leading to decreased electron density and average energy in discharge region, and thus decreasing the adsorption of oxygenated compounds [46]. Secondly, competitive adsorption of water molecules on active sites leads to a decrease of active sites available for reactant adsorption [47], especially for oxygenated reactant adsorption on acid sites [24]. Above all, the hydrophobicity of Pt-based catalyst improved by Nb2O5 helps the desorption of water from active sites, and thus promotes the reaction of oxygenated compounds during the HDO process, resulting in an enhanced reaction rate of guaiacol on unit of Pt metal site. Reaction mechanism of guaiacol HDO on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 In order to investigate the reaction route of guaiacol on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalyst, HDO of guaiacol was conducted at 320 °C and 4 MPa H2 over 1Pt2Nb (Fig. 8 a) and 1Pt0Nb (Fig. 8b), and the curves of the product yield and guaiacol conversion versus time were obtained. The products with yields below 1 % are not shown in Fig. 8a and 8b. When the temperature reached 320 °C, the reaction time was recorded as 0 min. For both catalysts, the guaiacol conversion reaches 100 % at around 900 min. As shown in Fig. 8a, the main products on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalyst are cyclohexane, methylcyclohexane, cyclohexanone, phenol, veratrole, catechol and 6-methylcatechol. The yield of the products phenol, veratrole, catechol and 6-methylcatechol increases first and then decreases within 0–1800 min, proving that they are intermediate products during the HDO reaction of guaiacol. While the yield of cyclohexane, methylcyclohexane and cyclohexanone increases over time. As shown in Fig. 8b, the detected products on 1Pt0Nb are similar to those on 1Pt2Nb. For both catalysts, the yield of catechol first increases within 0∼450 min, and then fluctuated within 450∼900 min, indicating that guaiacol is transformed into catechol, which is further transformed into phenol and 6-methylcatechol [48]. It is worth mentioning that when veratrole, catechol and 6-methylcatechol are reacted completely, the yield of phenol begins to decrease, but the cyclohexane significantly increases, indicating a reaction route of phenol transformation into cyclohexane. In addition, when guaiacol is reacted completely, the slope in the curve of phenol yield versus time decreases, indicating a reaction route of guaiacol transformation into phenol. When the 6-methylcatechol yield starts to decrease, the yield of methylcyclohexane significantly increases, indicating a route of 6-methylcatechol transformation into methylcyclohexane. To clarify the effect of Nb on the reaction route, the product distribution on γ-Al2O3, 2Nb, 1Pt0Nb and 1Pt2Nb were omparatively analyzed. Fig. 9 shows that catechol is the main product on both of γ-Al2O3 and 2Nb supports, which should be due to demethylation reaction of guaiacol [49]. The yield of benzene and toluene on 2Nb are more than that on γ-Al2O3, indicating that Nb2O5 promotes the C(sp2)-O cleavages reactions. On the other hand, the yield of cyclohexane and methylcyclohexane on 1Pt2Nb is much higher than that on 2Nb. As reported, [50,51] cyclohexane is obtained from phenol through a reaction route of phenol hydrogenation into cyclohexanone, which is hydrogenated into cyclohexanol and then dehydrated into cyclohexene, which is finally hydrogenated into cyclohexane on noble metal. Thus, Nb species promotes the deoxygenation reaction through accelerating the dehydration of cyclohexanol produced from phenol on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalyst. Moreover, the yield of catechol and 3-catechol that liberated water during the HDO process is smaller on 1Pt2Nb than on 1Pt0Nb. As reported [52], the C(sp2)-O cleavage of guaiacol on Pt/γ-Al2O3 occurs before the saturation of aromatic ring, indicating that Nb species promotes the deoxygenation reactions of catechol and 3-catechol into phenol and cresol. Thus, we propose six reaction pathways of guaiacol (the colored molecular are observed in the product sample shown in Scheme 2, and the black molecular are the proposed intermediate products): (1) through cleavage of C(sp2)–OCH3 bond, guaiacol reacts into phenol, which is hydrogenated into cyclohexanone, which is further hydrogenated into cyclohexanol[50], which is dehydrated into cyclohexene, which is rapidly hydrogenated to cyclohexane; (2) phenol is converted into benzene through C(sp2)-O cleavage; (3) guaiacol is demethylated into catechol, then catechol is alkylated into 6-methylcatechol, which is deoxygenated to produce o-methylphenol, which is deoxygenated into toluene, which is hydrogenated to produce methylcyclohexane; (5) guaiacol is demethylated into veratrole, which is alkylated into 6-methylveratrole, which is converted through the removal of two methoxy groups into toluene, which is further saturated to form methylcyclohexane, (6) through removal of methoxy group, veratrole is converted into anisole, which is converted through removal of methoxy group into benzene, which is hydrogenated into cyclohexane in metal center. The reaction route 1, 2 and 3 are the main pathway for the reaction of guaiacol on Pt/NbxAl2O3.3, since catechol is the main intermediate, as shown in Fig. 9. The intermediate products, such as toluene and cyclohexene, are not found in the cooled samples because the excellent hydrogenation performance of Pt NPs with C=C bond hydrogenated quickly at 300 °C with H2 pressure of 4 MPa. Above all, Nb2O5 does not change the main reaction routes of guaiacol on Pt/γ-Al2O3, but it accelerated the deoxygenation steps in HDO reaction. Role of Nb for HDO of guaiacol over Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalyst The above results show that the doped Nb has a favorable effect in the HDO reaction of guaiacol on the Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalyst. The role of Nb in HDO of guaiacol and the proposed reaction mechanism are depicted in Scheme 3. In the HDO reaction of guaiacol, guaiacol is first transformed into oxy-compounds, including anisole, catechol, phenol, methylcyclohexane and etc.), which are transformed into hydrocarbons. In both reaction steps, water is produced as a by-product on catalyst surface. The doping of Nb can effectively minimize the particle size of Pt due to the strengthened MSI, which provide more active metal sites for HDO reactions. However, excess Nb leads to partial coverage of Pt metal sites and thus decrease of hydrocarbons yield. Although Pt active sites are partially covered, the rHDO of guaiacol on unit of Pt metal sites still increases with increasing Nb content on catalysts due to the improved hydrophobicity of catalysts, which decreases the interaction between water molecules and the catalyst surface and thus promotes the forward reactions by accelerating desorption of water molecules from catalyst surface. Conclusion In summary, the efficient Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts were prepared to enhance both of HDO reaction rate (rHDO) on unit of Pt metal sites and hydrocarbons yield, and the structural−performance relationship was systematically studied. The acidity of Nb2O5 was removed by low molar content of Nb and high calcination temperature of NbxAl2O3.3 supports to rule out the effect of acidity as previously reported. Via multiple types of characterization (e.g., XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, H2O-TPD and contact angle analysis), it is found that the synergy between NbxAl2O3.3 and Pt significantly improves the catalytic performance significantly. On the one hand, Nb2O5 enhances the hydrophobicity of the catalyst surface and thus promotes desorption of water from active sites, resulting in enhanced HDO reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons from 0.024 (1Pt0Nb) to 0.032 min−1 (1Pt4Nb) on unit of Pt metal sites. On the other hand, Nb2O5 strengthens the MSI between Pt NPs and support, which minimize the size of Pt NPs and thus enhances the number of active sites for HDO reaction of guaiacol, resulting in higher hydrocarbons yield. However, excess amount of Nb causes partial coverage of Pt NPs, resulting in decrease of hydrocarbons yield. Furthermore, the effect of Nb on HDO reaction routes of guaiacol over Pt/NbxAl2O3.3 catalysts were clarified. The Pt-based catalyst with regulated surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion not only provides an approach for improving HDO efficiency of lignin compounds, but also processes a wide application prospect in water-liberated catalytic reactions Scheme 1 . coredata.dc:description: Transformation of lignin-derived feedstocks into valuable hydrocarbons is of significant importance but still challenging. This work investigates the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin compound guaiacol on Pt-based catalysts with improved surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion for the first time. The efficiency of guaiacol hydrodeoxygenation into hydrocarbons over Nb2O5-modified Pt-based catalyst reaches 51 %, nearly doubling that over unmodified Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (25 %). On the one hand, Nb2O5 causes the decrease of hydroxyl groups on catalyst, leading to the enhanced hydrophobicity of catalysts, which increases the reaction rate of guaiacol into hydrocarbons on unit of Pt metal sites. On the other hand, Nb2O5 strengthens the metal-support interaction, which minimizes the size of Pt nanoparticles, providing more exposed metal sites, thus leading to a higher hydrocarbons yield on catalyst. However, excess introduction of Nb2O5 leads to partial coverage of Pt metal sites, resulting in decreased yield of hydrocarbons. Furthermore, the routes of guaiacol HDO reaction over modified Pt-based catalysts are investigated. This work further illustrates the influence of catalyst surface properties on the HDO process of lignin compound, and thereby provides a promising approach for adjustment of catalyst surface properties in order to promote water-liberated reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Regulation of surface hydrophobicity and metal dispersion on Pt-based catalyst for the boosted hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol into bio-hydrocarbons
